content.description:
Insane and wild climbing on the right side of an arete. Oddly bolted, this line has difficult, tense movement with hard to clip bolts. Finish up a wide dihedral/off-sized crack to a chain anchor.

Begin climbing off the road under a large horn, traverse right towards the face, work up to a nice rest, then finish in the

Anniversary Crack

. Strenuous and very tough for the grade, this route is borderline ridiculous.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location:
Directly off the road, this is the middle-right bolted arete. Finish on

Anniversary Crack.

content.description: Low crux is tricky and insecure, but protected with a bolt. Pull past bolt into nice crack and plug a piece or two (large stoppers, #.75 and/or #1 BD C4). Step out right and make a few moves on perfect horizontal edges to the second bolt. Continue on edges straight up to horizontal break and another gear placement (small/medium stoppers, offsets can be helpful). Head straight up into tricky gaston moves and the final bolt. Reach out left then follow the arÃªte to the anchor.
content.protection: Three bolts supplemented with a few good gear placements.
content.location: Scramble up and start on the ledge just left of "92 In the Shade". A toprope can be arranged but is not advised.

content.description: This route is pumpy right off the ground. Clip the bolt and struggle up the slightly overhanging crack. The route ends with a bolted off-width.

Deceptively difficult, this beautiful arete offers hard, tricky climbing. An .11b for the area, balance and strength are among a few necessary skills; a good head and solid balls are among the others...

Scramble up a set of  chossy blocks and start climbng on the right side of the arete. Regardless of the temperature, it will still feel at least 92 in the shade! A real thriller.
content.protection: Six bolts to an anchor. (Some bolts are not shown in the pictue b/c they are on the opposite side of the arete)
content.location:
On the far right side of the

Roadside Fins

. This is the sharp, steep arete off the road.
